resources.string: This is the time at which CalendarTrigger was most recently called, either directly by the user, or as a result of an alarm set by CalendarTrigger itself.
This is the time of the alarm set by CalendarTrigger the last time it was called.
This button deletes the log file. The next attempt to write to the log will automatically recreate it, so this effectively clears the log.
This button displays the log file: Android will choose a suitable application to do this.
Cannot find a text editor to display log file
Error listing your agendas ; is Google Agenda installed ?
switched to silent for the event
switched to vibrate for the event
restored to vibrate after the event
restored to sound after the event
Long press here for help information.

This screen allows you to define the characteristics of class %s or delete it. When you have done, press the back button. A long press on any of the buttons below will bring up some help information about it.

This screen allows you to specify the conditions for a calendar event to be in class %s. All conditions must be satisfied for the event to be in the class, but each condition has a default option which is satisfied by any event. When you have done, press the back button. A long press on any of the controls below will bring up some help information about it.
An event is in class %s if:-
the event is in any of the calendars below which is checked

If no calendar is checked, the event can be in the class if it is in any calendar. Note that this is different from checking all calendars: if a new calendar is added later, it will not be checked unless you explicitly edit the class again.
An empty match string matches any event name or an event with no name at all.
An empty match string matches any event location or an event with no location at all.
An empty match string matches any event description or an event with no description at all.
Determine whether events which are busy, not busy, or either (the default), are in this class.
Determine whether events which are recurrent, not recurrent, or either (the default), are in this class.
Determine whether events for which you are the organiser, or not the organiser, or either (the default), are in this class.
Determine whether events which are private, public, or either (the default), are in this class.
Determine whether events which have attendees, or do not have attendees, or either (the default), are in this class.
This button deletes the class and cancels any actions scheduled for calendar events in this class. This action cannot be undone. The events themselves are not affected.
Conditions for a calendar event to be in class %s
Define the conditions for a calendar event to be in this class. An event can be in more than one class: in that case it will trigger the action(s) for each class it belongs to.
Define the conditions for the event start action(s) to be triggered for an event in this class.

This screen allows you to define when the start action(s) for an event in class %s will be triggered. This can be a set number of minutes (defaulting to zero) before the start time of the event, possibly delayed until the device is in some particular state. When you have done, press the back button. A long press on any of the controls below will bring up some help information about it.
Do start action(s) for an event in class %s:-

This defines the number of minutes (which may be zero) before the start time of the event at which CalendarTrigger will begin to consider triggering the event\'s start action(s). This may however be delayed by other conditions below
Here you can delay the start action(s) until the device is in some particular state.

Here you can delay the start action(s) until the device is in some particular orientation. If no box is checked, no orientation check is performed. The orientation check is performed every five minutes until it is satisfied. This can drain the battery if it has to wait for a long time.
Device is lying on a horizontal surface with the display facing upwards.
Device is lying on a horizontal surface with the display facing downwards.
Define the action(s) to be triggered at or before the start of an event in this class.

This button triggers a temporary event of this class which starts immediately and then ends immediately. It can be useful when the class provides a movement delay on its end action, if for example you walk into a quiet room and want to mute your ringer until you leave the room again.
This screen allows you to define what action(s) are performed for the start of an event in class %s. A long press on any of the controls below will bring up some help information about it.
At start of an event in class %s:-

This sets the state of the ringer during the event. CalendarTrigger will only set the ringer to a state \"weaker\" than it is already in, as set by the user or an overlapping event. Silent is weaker than vibrate which is weaker than normal ringtone.
If this is checked, CalendarTrigger will show a notification at the start of the event. The way in which the notification is presented depends on the user\'s notification settings.
Define the conditions for the event end action(s) to be triggered for an event in this class.

This screen allows you to define when the end action(s) for an event in class %s will be triggered. This can be a set number of minutes (defaulting to zero) after the end time of the event, possibly delayed until the device has moved by some distance or is in some particular state. When you have done, press the back button. A long press on any of the controls below will bring up some help information about it.
Do end action for an event in class %s:-

This defines the number of minutes (which may be zero) after the end time of the event at which CalendarTrigger will begin to consider triggering the event\'s end action. It may however be delayed by other conditions below.
Here you can delay the end action until something else has happened or the device is in some particular state.

Delay the end action until the user holding the device has taken a specified number of steps. This can be useful if the event is a meeting and you do not want to re-enable the ringer until the meeting has ended and you have walked out of the meeting room. A nonzero number will increase battery drain because the device has to monitor the step counter.
This option is disabled because the device does not support a step sensor.
The device has moved by the user taking

Delay the end action until the device has moved by a specified number of metres. This can be useful if the event is in a building and you do not want to re-enable the ringer until you have left the building. The position resolution is of the order of 100 metres (better if the building has Wi-Fi or the device uses GPS) so you should not make this number too small. If it is zero there is no movement test. A nonzero number will increase battery drain because the device has to monitor its position.

This option is disabled because CalendarTrigger does not have permission ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION to create a Geofence. You can enable this permission from the device\'s Settings tool by selecting the Application Manager.
Define the action(s) to be triggered at or after the end of an event in this class.
This screen allows you to define what actions are performed at the end of an event in class %s. A long press on any of the controls below will bring up some help information about it.
At end of an event in class %s:-

If this is checked, CalendarTrigger will restore the original ringer mode at the end of the event, provided that the user has not changed the mode in the meantime and no other overlapping event is requiring a \"weaker\" mode.
If this is checked, CalendarTrigger will show a notification at the end of the event. The way in which the notification is presented depends on the user\'s notification settings.
